author: kiltedturtle
comment:
>	Progressive U.S. lawmakers on Monday took House Republicans to task after the Congressional Budget Office said the erstwhile deficit hawks' first bill before the 118th Congress‚Äîa measure critics say is meant to "protect wealthy and corporate tax cheats"‚Äîwill swell the federal deficit by more than $100 billion.

>"They all run on reducing the deficit and now the House GOP's first... bill will increase the deficit by $114 billion," tweeted Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.). "Make it make sense."

>The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated that the euphemistically named Family and Small Business Taxpayer Protection Act‚Äîwhich faces a vote as soon as Monday evening‚Äîwould "decrease outlays by $71 billion and decrease receipts by $186 billion over the 2023-2032 period."

Ok, so this is the first law that will die in the Senate.  Whats next on the list?  The more time they spend on bills that will never get signed is fine.  They can pass crap like this all day.  And for what its worth, Biden has said he will veto it.   Not likely that the GQP will ever get to a veto-override on any of their bills in the next two terms.
[removed]

author: DriftlessDairy
comment:
The Republicans continue to defund the white-colar police.  
Specifically, they have pushed to defund:  
‚Ä¢ The US Chemical Safety Board, which polices major industrial accidents.  
‚Ä¢ The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which polices corporations‚Äô compliance with civil rights laws.  
‚Ä¢ The Consumer Products Safety Commission, which polices industries to make sure their products don‚Äôt harm or kill people. The agency now acknowledges that its ‚Äúfunding level has been insufficient to keep pace with the evolving consumer product marketplace.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ The Internal Revenue Service, which polices the tax system and which is responsible for making sure the wealthy and large corporations pay the taxes they owe. Thanks to this successful effort to defund the police, the agency ‚Äúconducted 675,000 fewer audits in 2017 than it did in 2010, a drop in the audit rate of 42 percent,‚Äù according to ProPublica. With 30,000 fewer tax cops on the beat, a recent Treasury Department report found that 800,000 high-income households have not paid more than $45 billion in owed taxes.  
‚Ä¢ The Department of Labor, which polices employers and makes sure they aren‚Äôt stealing wages, breaking workplace safety rules, ignoring overtime laws, and/or violating workers‚Äô union rights. Amid this particular Republican effort to defund the police, there are now fewer cops scrutinizing employers than ever before and workplace inspections have plummeted ‚Äì as workplace injuries, deaths and disasters have increased.  
‚Ä¢ The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which polices the accounting industry.  
‚Ä¢ The Securities and Exchange Commission‚Äôs reserve fund, which was established after the financial crisis to bolster the agency‚Äôs work policing Wall Street. The agency reports that the number of law enforcement staff ‚Äúsupporting our investigation and litigation efforts remained almost 9 percent lower‚Äù today than it was at the start of Trump‚Äôs term ‚Äì and now white collar prosecutions have hit a historic low.  
‚Ä¢ The law enforcement agencies that police corporate mergers. This effort to defund the antitrust police has come as mergers have accelerated (and there has been some recent effort to reverse the defunding).  
‚Ä¢ The independent law enforcement agency that policed agribusiness monopolies.  
‚Ä¢ The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which polices the financial industry and works to protect consumers from fraud.  
‚Ä¢ The law enforcement offices that police federal agencies and root out waste, fraud and abuse.  
‚Ä¢ The federal program that polices local law enforcement agencies.  
‚Ä¢ The Environmental Protection Agency, which is responsible for policing polluters. Trump‚Äôs first budget proposed to reduce EPA ‚Äúspending on civil and criminal enforcement by almost 60 percent,‚Äù and laying off 200 environmental cops, according to the New York Times. By the middle of Trump‚Äôs first year in office, the EPA had ‚Äúfewer than half of the criminal special agents on the job‚Äù during the George W. Bush administration, according to one environmental advocacy group. Bloomberg News noted that Trump‚Äôs most recent budget cuts ‚Äúcould hamper the EPA‚Äôs efforts to link contamination at hazardous waste sites to companies and others that may be responsible for the pollution.‚Äù The result: environmental prosecutions have now hit a historic low.  
Source post, with supporting links, [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/comments/hbzxek/comment/fvc18tv/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=web2x&context=3).

author: Marnever
comment: Why does this headline (like so many others) focus on the apparent response from the other side as opposed to the actual story? A far more succinct and useful headline would just be ‚ÄúHouse GOP Introduces Bill Adding $114 Billion to Deficit By Enabling Tax Cheats‚Äù. I don‚Äôt understand how we got to the point that the ‚Äúclap back‚Äù or the ‚Äúblast‚Äù or the ‚Äúslam‚Äù is the relevant part of any given story. Like yeah sure it‚Äôs good to note that democrats are criticizing this dumpster fire of a move, but that‚Äôs not the real meat and potatoes is it? The actual story that should be the focal point is that the republicans (who campaign endlessly on reducing the deficit) are doing the exact opposite of their promises just like anyone with a brain would expect. It‚Äôs just bizarre to me how so much of our discourse skirts around the bits that matter in order to pump up the fanfare and theatrics.

author: GuitarGeezer
comment:
A fair critique of the Republicans as they are clearly on the side of tax cheats here and are aggressively dishonest about tax reform. That being said, voters of both parties who have a problem with any of this need to seriously consider doing something more than nothing about campaign finance reform which may require a constitutional amendment-I am a federal practice attorney and know what I am talking about. 

     Tax policy and legislation in general is seldom done with a rational basis. Rather, those who finance the campaigns directly and through shadow spending using ‚Äòcharitables‚Äô are purchasing the right to directly draft federal laws in-house at their lobbies. Even bipartisan legislation (the bankruptcy heist of 2005 and the fixing of student loan laws and literally thousands of other laws) is usually just proof that both sides were purchased in a way that wasn‚Äôt anywhere near this bad prior to the 1980s until you go wayyy back. Congress staffs tell me when I lobby and complain that almost no voter has ever so much as complained to them in any way about our system of legalized bribery and coercion. Sometimes prior to 2010 I was the only person in my entire state bugging them about it. Sickening suicidal negligence by voters.
